title: 5 Unexpected Factors That Can Transform Your Mental Health
description: Mental health is not just a personal concern; it’s a business asset.
author: Clark Lagemann
excerpt: Mental health is not just a personal concern; it’s a business asset.
text: For entrepreneurs juggling endless tasks, stress, and decision-making, understanding the unexpected ways mental health influences success can unlock new levels of productivity and resilience.  For over a decade, I’ve been leading companies and running startups, navigating the nonstop demands of entrepreneurship. I’ve faced the long hours, the high-stakes decisions, and the stress that comes with building something from the ground up. So when entrepreneurs talk about juggling endless tasks, I know exactly what they mean. I’ve researched, tested, and refined countless strategies to improve mental well-being, and these are the five I found most effective for unlocking new levels of productivity and resilience. 1. Stress can be good—if you learn to harness it For entrepreneurs, stress often feels like an ever-present companion. The good news? Not all stress is bad. Positive stress, or “eustress,” can help you stay focused and motivated when tackling critical business challenges like investor pitches or product launches​. However, chronic stress can quickly spiral into burnout. The key is learning to recognize and channel eustress while mitigating harmful stress. Entrepreneurs can leverage strategies like reframing challenges as opportunities or practicing mindfulness to transform stress from an enemy into an ally. 2. Your gut health shapes your resilience The saying “you are what you eat” is true for everyone, particularly when it comes to brain function and mental health. Your gut microbiome—a diverse ecosystem of trillions of bacteria—directly impacts your mental health. The gut produces about 90 percent of serotonin and 50 percent of dopamine, critical chemicals for mood regulation. Recent research published in Nature Mental Health revealed that individuals with healthier gut microbiomes—marked by anti-inflammatory bacterial activity and strong gut barrier integrity—are more resilient to stress. While science hasn’t yet pinpointed exact solutions, you can benefit from experimenting with gut-friendly foods like kimchi, yogurt, and sauerkraut.  3. Strength training is a mental health booster Entrepreneurs often juggle high-pressure situations, making anxiety a common companion. Strength training, however, is a powerful yet underutilized tool for managing mental health. Research shows that both single sessions and long-term resistance training can reduce anxiety symptoms significantly. The key lies in low-to-moderate intensity workouts, typically performed at 40-70 percent of your one-rep max​​. Resistance training produces robust changes in neurobiological systems, which are central to anxiety management. The best part? You don’t need heavy weights or a gym membership to reap the benefits. Simple routines using resistance bands, bodyweight exercises like squats and push-ups, or light dumbbells can help reduce anxiety while building resilience.  4. Ultra-processed foods take a toll on your mood Ultra-processed foods like sugary snacks, sodas, and fast food might seem convenient during a busy day, but they can have a steep cost. Diets high in ultra-processed foods are linked to a 20-50 percent increased risk of depressive symptoms. By replacing these foods with whole, nutrient-dense options like fresh vegetables, lean proteins, and healthy fats, you can improve your energy, focus, and decision-making abilities. Small changes in your diet can lead to big changes in your mental wellbeing. 5. The benefits of gratitude practices Gratitude is more than a feel-good concept; it’s a scientifically supported practice that can significantly enhance mental health. Studies have shown that that individuals who kept a gratitude journal experienced improved emotional well-being. For entrepreneurs constantly pushing toward the next big goal, taking a moment to reflect on what’s already been achieved helps shift focus from stress-inducing challenges to positive outcomes.  Gratitude practices also contribute to better interpersonal relationships, which play a critical role in entrepreneurial success. Whether it’s a simple “thank you” to a team member or a note of appreciation to a mentor, these small acts can enhance team morale and collaboration. Over time, cultivating gratitude builds a positive work environment, improves emotional well-being, and creates a culture that encourages both personal and professional growth. As someone who’s faced the ups and downs of entrepreneurship, I know firsthand how challenging it can be to prioritize mental health while building a business. That’s why I’ve worked to incorporate many of these strategies into my own life. These intentional changes have made a measurable difference in my focus, resilience, and overall performance.
html:
For entrepreneurs juggling endless tasks, stress, and decision-making, understanding the unexpected ways mental health influences success can unlock new levels of productivity and resilience.  

For over a decade, I’ve been leading companies and running startups, navigating the nonstop demands of entrepreneurship. I’ve faced the long hours, the high-stakes decisions, and the stress that comes with building something from the ground up. So when entrepreneurs talk about juggling endless tasks, I know exactly what they mean. I’ve researched, tested, and refined countless strategies to improve mental well-being, and these are the five I found most effective for unlocking new levels of productivity and resilience. 

1. Stress can be good—if you learn to harness it 

For entrepreneurs, stress often feels like an ever-present companion. The good news? Not all stress is bad. Positive stress, or “eustress,” can help you stay focused and motivated when tackling critical business challenges like investor pitches or product launches​. 

However, chronic stress can quickly spiral into burnout. The key is learning to recognize and channel eustress while mitigating harmful stress. Entrepreneurs can leverage strategies like reframing challenges as opportunities or practicing mindfulness to transform stress from an enemy into an ally. 

2. Your gut health shapes your resilience 

The saying “you are what you eat” is true for everyone, particularly when it comes to brain function and mental health. Your gut microbiome—a diverse ecosystem of trillions of bacteria—directly impacts your mental health. The gut produces about 90 percent of serotonin and 50 percent of dopamine, critical chemicals for mood regulation. 

Recent research published in Nature Mental Health revealed that individuals with healthier gut microbiomes—marked by anti-inflammatory bacterial activity and strong gut barrier integrity—are more resilient to stress. While science hasn’t yet pinpointed exact solutions, you can benefit from experimenting with gut-friendly foods like kimchi, yogurt, and sauerkraut.  

3. Strength training is a mental health booster 

Entrepreneurs often juggle high-pressure situations, making anxiety a common companion. Strength training, however, is a powerful yet underutilized tool for managing mental health. Research shows that both single sessions and long-term resistance training can reduce anxiety symptoms significantly. The key lies in low-to-moderate intensity workouts, typically performed at 40-70 percent of your one-rep max​​. 

Resistance training produces robust changes in neurobiological systems, which are central to anxiety management. The best part? You don’t need heavy weights or a gym membership to reap the benefits. Simple routines using resistance bands, bodyweight exercises like squats and push-ups, or light dumbbells can help reduce anxiety while building resilience.  

4. Ultra-processed foods take a toll on your mood 

Ultra-processed foods like sugary snacks, sodas, and fast food might seem convenient during a busy day, but they can have a steep cost. Diets high in ultra-processed foods are linked to a 20-50 percent increased risk of depressive symptoms. 

By replacing these foods with whole, nutrient-dense options like fresh vegetables, lean proteins, and healthy fats, you can improve your energy, focus, and decision-making abilities. Small changes in your diet can lead to big changes in your mental wellbeing. 

5. The benefits of gratitude practices 

Gratitude is more than a feel-good concept; it’s a scientifically supported practice that can significantly enhance mental health. Studies have shown that that individuals who kept a gratitude journal experienced improved emotional well-being. For entrepreneurs constantly pushing toward the next big goal, taking a moment to reflect on what’s already been achieved helps shift focus from stress-inducing challenges to positive outcomes.  

Gratitude practices also contribute to better interpersonal relationships, which play a critical role in entrepreneurial success. Whether it’s a simple “thank you” to a team member or a note of appreciation to a mentor, these small acts can enhance team morale and collaboration. Over time, cultivating gratitude builds a positive work environment, improves emotional well-being, and creates a culture that encourages both personal and professional growth. 

As someone who’s faced the ups and downs of entrepreneurship, I know firsthand how challenging it can be to prioritize mental health while building a business. That’s why I’ve worked to incorporate many of these strategies into my own life. These intentional changes have made a measurable difference in my focus, resilience, and overall performance.
